title: Laundry on Chol HaMoed
vignette: Some tourists have run out of clean clothes during the intermediate festival days. Is washing permitted?

options.text: Yes, if no clean garments remain.
No laundry at all during the festival.

title: Professional work for pay
vignette: A scribe is asked to copy documents for pay during Chol HaMoed. Earnings are needed to cover his festival expenses.

options.text: He may work to prevent financial loss.
He should refrain and rely on savings.

title: Trimming hair before a funeral
vignette: A mourner learns of a relative's passing during the festival and wants a haircut before the funeral.

options.text: Allow the haircut due to honouring the deceased.
Haircuts remain forbidden even in mourning.

title: Repairing a collapsed wall
vignette: Heavy rain knocks down a section of backyard wall on Chol HaMoed. Leaving it open poses security risks.

options.text: Rebuild it temporarily to safeguard the property.
Delay repairs until after the festival.

title: Watering plants
vignette: The garden is wilting. May one water ornamental plants that aren't essential for food?

options.text: Water them sparingly to prevent loss.
No watering non-essential plants.

title: Writing personal letters
vignette: A traveler wishes to send holiday greetings home. Is casual letter writing permitted?

options.text: Yes; personal letters of joy are allowed.
Avoid writing except for business needs.

title: Engagement parties
vignette: A couple wants to hold their engagement celebration during Chol HaMoed. Some argue it mixes two distinct joys.

options.text: Hold the party; joy is appropriate now.
Delay until after the festival.

title: Fixing shoes
vignette: A sandal strap snaps while walking. Can it be repaired by a professional cobbler?

options.text: Yes; minor repairs that prevent discomfort are allowed.
No; wear different shoes until after the festival.

title: Court sessions on Chol HaMoed
vignette: A civil dispute is scheduled for the intermediate days. Should the court postpone the hearing?

options.text: Hold the session to deliver timely justice.
Delay legal proceedings until after the holiday.

title: Plowing a field for the festival
vignette: A farmer wants to prepare next season's field during Chol HaMoed so visitors can watch. It is not urgent for crop survival.

options.text: He may plow for the sake of the festival crowd.
Plowing for later benefit is prohibited.

title: Weaving cloth
vignette: A woman has free time and wants to continue a weaving project at home. The cloth won't be needed until months later.

options.text: Weaving can wait; avoid weekday labor.
She may weave casually for enjoyment.

title: Public mourning gatherings
vignette: A respected teacher dies during the festival. Should large public eulogies be held right away?

options.text: Hold modest funerals and wait with full eulogies.
Proceed with full honors despite the festival.

title: Excommunication announcements
vignette: A community member persistently flouts norms. Leaders want to issue a ban during Chol HaMoed to pressure him.

options.text: Announce the ban now to protect others.
Postpone until after the holiday.

title: Learning a new trade
vignette: During days off from regular work, one considers taking short lessons in a craft. Is this self-improvement allowed?

options.text: Permissible since it's for livelihood.
Better to focus on holiday spirit instead.

title: Cutting nails
vignette: Are ordinary people allowed to trim their nails during Chol HaMoed, or is it restricted like haircuts?

options.text: Trimming nails is allowed.
It should be avoided unless necessary.
